Understanding of macroeconomic theory

I effectively learned the foundations of the Macroeconomic theory. The formal and rigorous approach to these foundations was a remarkable takeaway of this course.  Moreover, I developed some important programming skills and software (Matlab) knowledge. In the theoretical part, I was happy to realize how the course taught me skills (dynamic programming, competitive markets, ...) that allow me to approach a wide variety of problems and models rather than one only specific context.

The strength are that the intellectual engagement required from the student was low; some may think this is a weakness -- I certainly do.

The course could be improved by actually teaching.

The course could connect to the real world more by talking about when the models work well and when they don't, and what one can accomplish with them (for example, when they have been successfully used for predictions or policy recommendations). For someone who will not work in macro theory, knowing the technical details of a bunch of models is not so useful, since I will probably never use them outside these courses. It would be much more helpful to focus on how to construct models, how to tell if/when they are good, and how to use them.

So I'm going to break my anonymity here by saying I took this class an undergrad who intends to go on to econ grad school. So my recommendation will only apply to someone in my shoes.

I know in the PhD info sessions they advise against taking grad classes. From the perspective of getting into grad schools, this might be good advice. I did below average and wouldn't be surprised if that ends up dinging me. If you're looking for a less "risky" econ grad class, I'd recommend looking to the electives. This term I also took a second year grad class and  (I think) did above average. My hypothesis for why it is easier to do better in the second year classes is either 1) grades matter less for older students or 2) they simply have much more on their plates. 

But let's say you're someone who doesn't care much about grades, who loves macro, and who seriously wants to attend an econ phd program. I would highly recommend this class. This class is not just like Macro Theory extended -- I've learned more macro than all my prior undergrad classes combined! It's a super cool feeling to be reading an Econ paper from the 80s, wonder why they didn't use a model you've learned about in class, and then realize that it's because the model was invented in the 90s. The professors are amazing and the PhD students are as well! 

You should be very comfortable with Analysis (bare minimum Math 230/231 or Math 300). Bare minimum in terms of Econ background, I'd say, is Macro Theory (or maybe Intermediate Macro and some more theoretical elective). You should probably be a Junior and I would also recommend trying to coerce a friend into taking the class with you (the psets are long and it's much more fun to work with someone).
